questions.text: What surgical procedure that is used to manage congenital glaucoma involves surgery from an ab interno approach?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Goniotomy is a type of goniosurgery used primarily for congenital glaucoma.
  • It is performed via an ab interno approach, meaning from within the anterior chamber.
  • A special knife or needle is introduced across the anterior chamber under gonioscopic guidance.

Mechanism:

  • The procedure involves incising the trabecular meshwork (TM) to create a direct channel between the anterior chamber and Schlemm's canal.
  • This is done to improve aqueous outflow and lower intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • The goal is physiologic restoration of outflow, unlike filtration surgery, which bypasses natural pathways.

Indications:

  • Most effective for primary congenital glaucoma, especially when the cornea is clear.
  • Trabeculotomy is preferred when corneal opacity prevents proper visualization of the angle.
  • It can also be used in secondary glaucomas, though outcomes may vary.

Intraoperative Technique:

  • Requires a clear view of angle structures, typically under general anesthesia using a Koeppe lens or mirrored goniolens.
  • The eye is tilted for optimal visualization.
  • A small corneal incision is made; a goniotomy knife is passed across the anterior chamber.
  • The mid-trabecular meshwork is incised under direct view; typically, 4-6 clock hours of TM are incised.
  • Viscoelastic may be used to maintain the anterior chamber depth.
  • Postoperative hyphema is common but usually mild.

Advantages:

  • Improves natural outflow by removing blockage in TM.
  • Ab interno approach minimizes external tissue disruption.
  • Contrasts with trabeculectomy or shunt surgeries, which are ab externo and create alternate outflow pathways.

Explanation of other options:

Aqueous shunt implantation (Option A): Involves placing a drainage tube into the anterior chamber and connecting it to a plate in the subconjunctival space. It is performed from outside the eye (ab externo) and is reserved for refractory or complex cases.

Trabeculectomy (Option B): A filtering surgery where a fistula is created between the anterior chamber and the subconjunctival space. Performed externally, often used when goniotomy/trabeculotomy fails or is not feasible.

Trabeculotomy (Option C): A probe is inserted into Schlemm's canal from the sclera and rotated into the anterior chamber to break the trabecular meshwork. It is also done from an external approach, though suitable in cases with a cloudy cornea where goniotomy is not possible.

Goniotomy

questions.text: The parents of a 4-month-old boy noted that their son is unusually sensitive to light and has tearing in both eyes. They have also noted that their child has developed 'large eyes' and they are unable to see his pupils. What is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Primary congenital glaucoma accounts for about 50-70% of all congenital glaucoma. Approximately 65% of patients with this condition are male, and 70% have bilateral involvement. The diagnosis of primary congenital glaucoma is made during the first year of life in 80% of cases.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma classically presents with the triad of epiphora, photophobia, and blepharospasm in an infant. The infant eye enlarges in response to elevated IOP producing buphthalmos. Tears in Descemet's membrane, called Haab striae, may occur from corneal stretching. Corneal edema may develop in association with Haab striae and IOP elevation.
  • Nasolacrimal duct obstruction typically produces epiphora, but does not explain the findings of corneal edema and buphthalmos in this infant. Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy and cystinosis can produce corneal clouding at birth, but not buphthalmos.
  • The remaining three options are causes of corneal clouding. But in NLD obstruction, we don't see corneal involvement.

questions.text: What condition is associated with both ectopia lentis and pupillary block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Weill-Marchesani syndrome is a connective tissue disorder characterized by:
    • Microspherophakia (small, spherical lens)
    • Ectopia lentis (lens subluxation or dislocation)
    • Short stature, brachydactyly, and joint stiffness
  • The small, spherical lens can shift forward and cause pupillary block, which leads to secondary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • This makes Weill-Marchesani syndrome unique in being associated with both ectopia lentis and pupillary block.

Explanation of other options:

Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis (Option B): Chronic low-grade uveitis with heterochromia. Associated with open-angle glaucoma due to trabeculitis or peripheral anterior synechiae. Not associated with ectopia lentis or pupillary block.

Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome (Option C): Anterior segment dysgenesis disorder. May present with corectopia, prominent Schwalbe's line, and iris strands. Associated with developmental open-angle glaucoma. Not linked with ectopia lentis or pupillary block.

Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) Syndrome (Option D): Acquired disorder involving abnormal corneal endothelium and iris changes. Typically presents in young to middle-aged women with unilateral secondary open-angle glaucoma. Not associated with lens dislocation or pupillary block.

questions.text: What anatomical modification is found in increased frequency in primary congenital glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary Congenital Glaucoma (PCG) is a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle structures that causes impaired aqueous outflow and leads to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). It is diagnosed within the first year of life in most cases and is often bilateral;

  1. Elevated IOP in infants leads to globe enlargement because the collagen in the infant eye is soft and more elastic.
  2. This stretching manifests as:
    • Increased axial length
    • Increased corneal diameter
    • Buphthalmos (large eyes)
  3. These changes lead to myopia, not hyperopia. (Option C ruled out)
  4. Axial length measurement via ultrasound is a useful diagnostic and monitoring tool in pediatric glaucomas.
  5. With successful treatment, axial elongation may normalize over time.

Hence, increased axial length is a hallmark anatomical modification in PCG due to the elevated IOP acting on a structurally immature eye.

Explanation of other options:

Hypoplastic optic nerve (Option A): Not a feature of PCG. The optic disc in PCG may show glaucomatous cupping, which interestingly can be reversible after surgical IOP control in infants.

Decreased corneal diameter (Option D): PCG typically shows increased corneal diameter. A corneal diameter >12 mm in a neonate strongly suggests glaucoma. Haab's striae and corneal edema are other classic signs.

questions.text: What is the most common inheritance pattern for Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is a rare, autosomal dominant developmental disorder that affects both the ocular anterior segment and extraocular neural crest-derived tissues. It is part of a spectrum that includes Axenfeld anomaly, Rieger anomaly, and Rieger syndrome, now collectively referred to as ARS.

Pathogenesis and Genetics

  • Developmental arrest in late gestation leads to retention of primordial endothelium and neural crest-derived tissue over the iris and angle structures.
  • This results in anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line (posterior embryotoxon), angle anomalies, and iris abnormalities.
  • Genetic mutations commonly associated:
    • PITX2 (4q25)
    • FOXC1 (6p25)
    • PAX6
  • The condition follows autosomal dominant inheritance with variable expressivity.

Ocular Manifestations

  • Bilateral involvement
  • Posterior embryotoxon (white line at corneal periphery; Schwalbe's line displaced anteriorly)
  • Iris strands extending to Schwalbe's line
  • Iris abnormalities:
    • Corectopia (displaced pupil)
    • Polycoria (multiple pupils)
    • Iris atrophy
    • Ectropion uveae
  • Abnormal angle tissue → predisposes to glaucoma (occurs in ~50% of cases)

Systemic Features

ARS is a syndrome and not just an ocular anomaly because of its extraocular involvement, particularly in neural crest-derived structures:

  • Dental: microdontia, hypodontia, anodontia (peg-like, missing, or absent teeth)
  • Facial: maxillary hypoplasia, telecanthus, flat midface, hypertelorism
  • Genitourinary: hypospadias (in males)
  • Pituitary: empty sella syndrome, other pituitary abnormalities
  • Redundant periumbilical skin

Management of Glaucoma in ARS

  • Topical therapy:
    • Most effective: β-blockers, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, short-term α-agonists
    • Less effective: Prostaglandin analogs, miotics (pilocarpine)
  • Surgical:
    • First-line: Trabeculectomy with antimetabolites (e.g., mitomycin C)
    • Alternatives: Goniotomy, tube shunt implants in refractory cases

A- Rieger anomaly - posterior embryotoxon +

B- corectopia, iris atrophy, sclerocornea,

C- excessive periumbilical skin

D- facial and dental anomalies

Explanation of other options:

Sporadic (Option A): Although some cases occur sporadically due to de novo mutations, most Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome cases are inherited, not sporadic.

X-linked (Option B): Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is not X-linked; the causative genes (PITX2, FOXC1) are located on autosomal chromosomes, not the X chromosome.

Autosomal recessive (Option D): While some developmental eye disorders are autosomal recessive, Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is typically autosomal dominant, with rare exceptions.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy with bilateral iris atrophy and corectopia is found to have elevated intraocular pressures. His father has a similar condition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, suggested by the presence of bilateral iris atrophy, corectopia, and elevated intraocular pressure in a 14-year-old boy, along with a positive family history of similar ocular findings.

questions.text: Which ocular disease is characterized by the triad of iris heterochromia, iridocyclitis, and cataract?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI) presents with the classic triad:
    • Iris heterochromia (lighter color in the affected eye due to stromal atrophy and pigment loss)
    • Low-grade chronic iridocyclitis (often asymptomatic, with fine stellate keratic precipitates)
    • Posterior subcapsular cataract
  • It is typically unilateral and occurs in young to middle-aged adults.
  • May present with high intraocular pressure (IOP) and secondary open-angle glaucoma
  • Gonioscopy may show fine abnormal blood vessels in the anterior chamber angle (but no PAS or angle closure)

Explanation of other options:

Peters anomaly (Option B): Congenital anterior segment dysgenesis with central corneal opacity and iridocorneal adhesions. Not associated with heterochromia or iritis

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner-Schlossman syndrome) (Option C): Recurrent episodes of mild non-granulomatous anterior uveitis and very high IOP. No cataract or iris heterochromia

Iridocorneal endothelial (ICE) syndrome (Option D): Seen in young to middle-aged women; features include iris atrophy, corectopia, peripheral anterior synechiae, and secondary angle-closure glaucoma. No heterochromia or cataract typical of FHI

questions.text: Two months after developing a vitreous hemorrhage, a patient is found to have intraocular pressure of 50 mmHg. Khaki-colored cells are noted in the anterior chamber. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a history of vitreous hemorrhage, elevated intraocular pressure, and khaki-colored cells in the anterior chamber points towards the diagnosis of ghost cell glaucoma.

Ghost Cell Glaucoma - Summary

  • Cause: Secondary open-angle glaucoma due to rigid, khaki-colored RBCs (ghost cells) clogging the trabecular meshwork after a vitreous hemorrhage.
  • Onset: Appears 2-4 weeks after hemorrhage, often post-trauma or surgery (when hyaloid face is disrupted).
  • Signs: High IOP, khaki cells in the anterior chamber, normal angle on gonioscopy, possible corneal edema.
  • Treatment:
    • Start with IOP-lowering drops.
    • If ineffective, → anterior chamber washout or pars plana vitrectomy.

Explanation of other options:

Schwartz's syndrome (Option A): This is a rare secondary open-angle glaucoma seen in eyes with rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. It is caused by photoreceptor outer segments migrating through a retinal break and obstructing the trabecular meshwork, but khaki-colored cells are not seen.

Phacolytic glaucoma (Option B): Occurs in eyes with hypermature cataracts, where denatured lens proteins leak through the intact capsule, causing macrophage-mediated trabecular blockage. It presents with open angles and inflammatory cells, but not khaki-colored ghost cells.

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner-Schlossman syndrome) (Option C): A unilateral recurrent condition with mild non-granulomatous anterior uveitis and markedly elevated IOP. It presents with fine keratic precipitates and open angles but no vitreous hemorrhage or khaki-colored cells.

questions.text: Which syndrome is associated with weakening of zonules and glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of a fibrillar material in the anterior segment of the eye.
  • Exfoliative material is deposited on the iris, ciliary region and capsule of the lens. Clinically, these appear as flakes on the anterior capsule of the lens and the edge of the iris, and are particularly evident in the mid-peripheral region where the anterior capsule is rubbed upon by the iris; the axial region is usually free. Although the origin of this material is not precisely known, it probably arises from multiple sources as part of a generalized basement membrane disorder.
  • Deposition of pseudoexfoliation material on the lens zonules may lead to zonular weakness. The anterior chamber angle can often be narrow in patients with pseudoexfoliation, presumably as a result of the anterior movement of the lens-iris diaphragm related to zonular weakness. Pigment dispersion syndrome, UGH syndrome, and Sturge-Weber syndrome generally have an open angle, and narrowing of the anterior chamber angle is not typically observed in these syndromes.

questions.text: Congenital glaucoma is associated with what clinical finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tears in Descemet's membrane, known as Haab's striae, are characteristic of primary congenital glaucoma (PCG). They occur due to increased intraocular pressure (IOP) in infancy, leading to stretching and splitting of Descemet's membrane.
  • These appear as horizontal, linear, double-contoured corneal opacities and are seen along with corneal edema, photophobia, tearing, buphthalmos, and optic nerve cupping.
  • The diagnosis is clinical and based on signs like increased corneal diameter (>12 mm), increased axial length, and IOP >20 mmHg in calm infants.

Explanation of Other Options:

Peripheral anterior synechiae (Option A): Not a feature of PCG unless the child has undergone previous angle surgery or has secondary glaucoma; the angle is typically open in PCG with anterior iris insertion but no synechiae.

Optic nerve swelling (Option B): PCG leads to optic nerve cupping due to chronically elevated IOP, not swelling. Swelling would suggest papilledema or inflammation, not glaucoma.

Short axial length (Option D): PCG is associated with increased axial length due to globe stretching under elevated IOP. A short axial length would suggest microphthalmos or hyperopia, not congenital glaucoma.

choices.text: Inflammatory cells in the trabecular meshwork
Red blood cells in the trabecular meshwork

questions.text: When evaluating a patient with a traumatic hyphema, which of the following is the most likely cause of low intraocular pressure (IOP)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cyclodialysis cleft is the most likely cause of low IOP in the setting of traumatic hyphema.
  • It involves the separation of the ciliary body from the scleral spur, creating a direct communication between the anterior chamber and suprachoroidal space, leading to increased outflow and ocular hypotony.
  • This appears on gonioscopy as a deep angle recession with a visible gap, and ultrasound biomicroscopy can assist in diagnosis.

Additionally:

  • After ocular trauma, IOP may be low, normal, or high during the initial period.
  • Low IOP can result from:
    • Ciliary body contusion/inflammation → decreased aqueous production
    • Cyclodialysis cleft → increased aqueous outflow
    • Globe rupture or loss of ocular wall integrity → external aqueous leakage
  • Importantly, normal or low IOP early on does not rule out the later development of glaucoma, which typically results from reduced aqueous outflow facility due to trabecular meshwork damage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Inflammatory cells in the trabecular meshwork (Option A): These block outflow and cause raised IOP, not low IOP.

Red blood cells in the trabecular meshwork (Option C): They can clog the trabecular meshwork post-hyphema, leading to secondary IOP elevation, not hypotony.

Pupillary block (Option D): Leads to acute angle closure and elevated IOP, especially when a clot obstructs aqueous flow between the chambers.

questions.text: A mutation in the TIGR/myocilin gene is associated with which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Juvenile open-angle glaucoma (JOAG) is a rare, early-onset form of glaucoma occurring within the first two decades of life, often requiring surgical therapy due to significantly elevated IOP.
  • It is frequently autosomal dominant, and linkage studies in large pedigrees led to the identification of the MYOC gene (GLC1A) located on chromosome 1q23, which encodes myocilin.
  • Myocilin is expressed in the trabecular meshwork, ciliary body, and retina. Nearly all pathogenic mutations occur in its olfactomedin domain, although its exact function is still unknown.
  • These mutations do not cause disease by loss of function (haploinsufficiency), since individuals with one or no functional copy do not develop glaucoma. Rather, they are believed to cause gain-of-function or dominant-negative effects, resulting in protein misfolding, endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, and cellular dysfunction in the trabecular meshwork.
  • Only 10-20% of JOAG patients carry MYOC mutations, indicating that other genes may also play a role.
  • MYOC mutations, especially GLN368X, are also associated with some adult-onset primary open-angle glaucoma cases.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pigment dispersion syndrome (Option B): Involves mechanical iris-zonule friction, releasing pigment, which clogs the trabecular meshwork. Not associated with MYOC mutations.

Pseudoexfoliation (Option C): A systemic disorder characterized by deposition of fibrillar material on ocular structures; strongly associated with LOXL1 gene mutations, not myocilin.

Nanophthalmos (Option D): A rare condition with small but structurally normal eyes, typically associated with MFRP or TMEM98 gene mutations.

questions.text: What is the least common extraocular abnormality in Rieger syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rieger syndrome is part of the spectrum of bilateral, hereditary, anterior-segment dysgenesis resulting from the developmental arrest of neural crest cells (neuroectoderm).
  • Axenfeld's anomaly is characterized by posterior embryotoxon (prominent anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line) with prominent iris processes.
  • Rieger's anomaly is Axenfeld's anomaly in addition to iris abnormalities, including stromal hypoplasia, ectropion uveae, corectopia, or iris holes.
  • Rieger's syndrome is Rieger's anomaly with a developmentally associated extra-ocular abnormality, such as microdontia (small teeth), hypodontia (fewer teeth), and craniofacial abnormalities are most commonly observed because teeth and facial bones are derived from neural crest cells. Less common extra-ocular findings include umbilical anomalies, cardiac malformations, and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy has unilateral cutaneous facial redness, ipsilateral glaucoma, and hemiplegia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a sporadic neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by congenital vascular hamartomas of the skin (nevus flammeus), eye, and brain.
  • The classic triad includes:
    • Facial port-wine stain in the trigeminal distribution
    • Ipsilateral leptomeningeal angioma → leading to seizures, hemiplegia, and intracranial calcifications (railroad track sign on CT)
    • Glaucoma (present in ~70% cases, often before 2 years)
  • Ocular findings also include:
    • Diffuse choroidal hemangioma (leading to "tomato ketchup fundus")
    • Prominent episcleral vessels
    • Retinal vascular tortuosity
  • The presence of unilateral facial angioma, ipsilateral glaucoma, and neurological symptoms like hemiplegia in this child fits the Roach Type I SWS, the classic form with both skin and CNS involvement.
  • The GNAQ gene mutation has been identified in both skin and ocular lesions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nevus of Ota (Option B): Presents with bluish periocular pigmentation and melanocytosis of sclera/uvea; not associated with brain involvement, hemiplegia, or facial vascular malformations.

Neurofibromatosis (Option C): Characterized by café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and optic gliomas; skin lesions are melanocytic, not vascular. No leptomeningeal angioma or facial port-wine stain.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option D): Involves hypopigmented macules, cortical tubers, seizures, and hamartomas, but no facial port-wine stain or glaucoma from vascular malformations.

choices.text: Spoke like radial iris transillumination defects

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic sign of pigment dispersion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pigment dispersion syndrome (PDS) is a condition typically seen in young adults, particularly males aged 20-40 years, and may lead to pigmentary glaucoma.
  • The hallmark feature is spoke-like mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects caused by rubbing between the posterior iris pigment epithelium and the lens zonules, leading to pigment loss.
  • The released pigment accumulates in:
    • Trabecular meshwork (can raise IOP)
    • Corneal endothelium (Krukenberg spindle)
    • Posterior lens capsule (Scheie stripe)
  • Loss of iris concavity and deep anterior chamber are other supporting findings.

Genetics & Pathophysiology:

  • It may be autosomal dominant.
  • Genetic locus identified on chromosome 7q35-q36; PMEL gene mutations (premelanosome protein) implicated.
  • TYRP1 and GPNMB genes contribute to pigment dispersion in mice but are not involved in humans.

Explanation of Other Options:

Blood in Schlemm's canal (Option A): Seen in conditions with elevated episcleral venous pressure, not in PDS.

Iris bombe (Option B): Seen in pupillary block angle-closure glaucoma, where the iris bows forward due to blocked aqueous flow, not a feature of PDS.

Peripupillary atrophy (Option D): Commonly associated with pseudoexfoliation syndrome, not pigment dispersion.

choices.text: Glaucoma associated with elevated episcleral venous pressure

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has recurrent episodes of markedly elevated IOP and low-grade anterior chamber inflammation. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner-Schlossman syndrome) is a rare type of open-angle glaucoma typically affecting middle-aged adults. It usually presents with unilateral eye pain and blurred vision associated with markedly increased IOP (40-60 mm Hg). A mild iritis is present and resolves spontaneously within a few weeks. The IOP usually remains normal between episodes, but a chronic secondary glaucoma may develop with an increasing number of attacks. Angle-recession glaucoma, glaucoma associated with elevated episcleral venous pressure, and exfoliation glaucoma are all chronic forms of glaucoma that are not typically associated with ocular inflammation.

questions.text: Which variant of iridocorneal endothelial (ICE) syndrome predominantly has corneal changes with minimal iris abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chandler's syndrome is a variant of ICE syndrome that is associated with predominant corneal changes

ICE syndrome is a sporadic, unilateral disorder affecting young to middle-aged adults (20-50 years), more commonly women. It is a spectrum of diseases characterized by abnormal corneal endothelium, iris atrophy, and secondary angle-closure glaucoma, often with peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS). It includes three clinical variants:

  1. Chandler's Syndrome (most common ~50%):
    • Minimal iris changes, possible mild corectopia.
    • Corneal edema is the hallmark; edema may be present even with normal IOP.
    • Angle appears open but is functionally closed by the abnormal endothelial membrane.
  2. Progressive Iris Atrophy (essential iris atrophy):
    • Severe iris atrophy with corectopia, pseudopolycoria, ectropion uveae, and iris holes. (Option C ruled out)
    • Most dramatic iris changes among ICE variants.
  3. Cogan-Reese Syndrome (Iris Nevus Syndrome): Milder iris atrophy with pigmented pedunculated nodules on the iris. (Option D ruled out)

Clinical Presentation:

  • Unilateral symptoms: decreased vision, pain, corectopia, or visible iris holes.
  • Microcystic corneal edema, more in the morning.
  • Secondary glaucoma (open- or angle-closure), often difficult to control.

Explanation of Other Options:

Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome (Option B): Congenital and bilateral; features anterior segment dysgenesis (posterior embryotoxon, iris hypoplasia), not part of ICE spectrum.

questions.text: Lens extraction will not resolve glaucoma in which of the following situations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lens extraction might resolve glaucoma in microspherophakia, phacolytic glaucoma, and chronic primary angle closure glaucoma. Exfoliation syndrome glaucoma would not be substantially improved by cataract surgery. The material is produced by nonpigmented ciliary epithelium and other ocular tissues and can be found in pseudophakic and aphakic eyes on the capsule, vitreous, corneal endothelium, iris, and anterior chamber angle.

questions.text: Which ocular condition is associated with an increased risk of complications with cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patients with exfoliation syndrome have an increased risk of complications with cataract surgery, including lens dislocation and vitreous loss. Exfoliation syndrome may be associated with zonular weakness, and phacodonesis may be identified preoperatively in some cases. Additionally, patients with this condition often dilate poorly. Pigment dispersion syndrome, ocular hypertension, and angle recession have not been reported to increase the risk of cataract extraction.

choices.text: Inability to adequately view the trabecular meshwork in an eye with a narrow angle prior to performing laser trabeculoplasty

questions.text: Laser iridotomy is not indicated in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Laser iridotomy is indicated for phakic, pseudophakic, or aphakic pupillary block and for relative pupillary block (acute angle-closure and chronic angle-closure glaucoma). If an angle has no peripheral anterior synechiae, but is narrow enough to prevent performance of a laser trabeculoplasty, an iridotomy is appropriate.
  • In neovascular glaucoma, the iris is pulled into the trabecular meshwork by fibrovascular proliferation rather than pushed into the angle by a relative pupillary block. The former mechanism would not favorably respond to a laser iridotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not commonly seen in primary infantile glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Elevated intraocular pressure in primary infantile glaucoma causes a generalized enlargement of the globe. This can be manifested as an increased corneal diameter, progressive myopia, and breaks in Descemet's membrane. The anterior chamber angle is usually malformed, with a high iris insertion and the appearance of a membrane-like structure over the trabecular meshwork. A prominent, anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line, known as posterior embryotoxon, can be seen in Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome but is not typically associated with primary infantile glaucoma.

questions.text: Important evidence of progression of primary infantile glaucoma in an infant would not include which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amblyopia, although a complication of infantile glaucoma, does not indicate progression of IOP elevation.
  • It results from anisometropia, astigmatism, or visual deprivation and can develop even in well-controlled cases, making it not a reliable marker of disease progression.

Primary infantile glaucoma typically presents within the first 3 years of life and is caused by developmental anomalies of the anterior chamber angle.

  • Findings that indicate disease progression:
  • Progression of the disease in infants is not primarily monitored by optic nerve or visual field analysis (as in adults), but instead by structural changes due to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).
    1. Increasing axial length - due to the stretchable nature of the infantile sclera, elevated IOP leads to elongation of the eyeball. (Option A ruled out)
    2. Increasing horizontal corneal diameter - reflects globe enlargement. (Option C ruled out)
    3. Increasing myopia - the stretching of the eye induces axial myopia. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: What is the most common reason for long-term visual loss in primary infantile glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amblyopia is the most frequent cause of long-term visual loss in eyes with primary congenital glaucoma (PCG), despite good IOP control.
  • It results from sensory deprivation due to factors like significant anisometropia, uncorrected astigmatism, or early visual deprivation.
  • Amblyopia often occurs without visible structural changes in the fundus and may affect one or both eyes.
  • Early intervention with spectacles or occlusion therapy is crucial to prevent irreversible vision loss.

Explanation of Other Options:

Corneal edema (Option A): Frequently present in PCG due to high IOP but typically resolves after surgical intervention. It contributes less significantly to long-term visual loss.

Corneal scarring (Option C): Mild corneal scarring or Haab's striae (breaks in Descemets me'brane) can occur due to globe stretching, but these changes usually do not lead to substantial permanent visual impairment.

Glaucomatous optic nerve damage (Option D): Although possible, especially with persistently elevated IOP, it is not the most common cause of vision loss in PCG. Regular monitoring of the optic nerve is important, but amblyopia remains a more frequent challenge.

questions.text: The image shown is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows Haab's striae, which are horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Seen in Primary Congenital Glaucoma (PCG) due to corneal stretching from elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) in infancy.
  • Classic triad in PCG:
    • Epiphora (excess tearing)
    • Photophobia
    • Blepharospasm
  • Associated findings:
    • Buphthalmos (enlarged globe)
    • Increased corneal diameter
    • Corneal edema/opacification

Explanation of other options:

Wilson's Disease (Option A): Presents with Kayser-Fleischer rings (Greenish-golden or brownish ring at the peripheral cornea due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane). Not associated with Haab's striae.

Keratoconus (Option B): Features Vogt's striae, not Haab's. Vogt's striae are vertical stress lines in posterior stroma, disappear on corneal pressure. Progressive thinning and conical protrusion of cornea.

Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (PEX) (Option D): Characterized by deposition of whitish fibrillar material on anterior lens capsule, iris, and trabecular meshwork. Associated with secondary open-angle glaucoma due to blocked aqueous outflow. No Haab's striae.

questions.text: A newborn child presents with watering, and on examination, the following image is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image and clinical signs are characteristic of buphthalmos, which is seen in Primary Congenital Glaucoma (PCG).
  • PCG typically presents in infancy with a triad of:
    • Epiphora (excessive tearing)
    • Photophobia
    • Blepharospasm
  • Due to elevated intraocular pressure, the immature eye structures stretch, resulting in:
    • Enlarged cornea and globe (buphthalmos)
    • Haab's striae (horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane)
    • Corneal edema/opacification

Explanation of other options:

Megalocornea (Option A): Non-progressive bilateral corneal enlargement (>13 mm) without raised IOP. No associated Haab's striae.

Congenital cataract (Option C): Presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex), not with globe enlargement or tearing.

Congenital Dacryocystitis (Option D): Infection of nasolacrimal sac causing swelling near the inner canthus, not globe enlargement.

questions.text: In which condition do we see such a sign on the lens capsule?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the accumulation of fibrillar extracellular material throughout the anterior segment.
  • On the anterior lens capsule, this material forms a characteristic "target sign" or "bull's eye pattern":
    • A central disc (cleared by the rubbing of the pupil),
    • A clear intermediate zone (due to iris movement),
    • And a granular peripheral zone (where material accumulates).
  • This pattern is created due to the mechanical rubbing of the iris on the lens during pupillary movement.
  • The condition also leads to zonular weakness, poor mydriasis, and secondary open-angle glaucoma due to deposition in the trabecular meshwork.

Explanation of Other Options:

Vogt Triad (Option B): Refers to signs of keratoconus- Fleischer ring (iron deposition), Vogt's striae (stromal stress lines), and Corneal thinning. It is not related to any capsular sign or lens findings.

Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome(Option C): A developmental anterior segment dysgenesis involving posterior embryotoxon, iris strands, corectopia, and systemic abnormalities. It may involve the lens position or iris insertion, but does not produce pseudoexfoliative material or capsular rings.

Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) Syndrome (Option D): Characterized by corneal endothelial changes, peripheral anterior synechiae, and iris atrophy or nodules. No pseudoexfoliative material is seen; lens capsule changes are not a feature of ICE.
